content: quote: Originally posted by SUNLINER81: It may go nuclear and quick, with a "nuke" strike on Seoul and a retaliatory strike by the U.S. on the N.Korean capital of Pyongyang... The N.Korean army would, if they hadn't already, pour across the border in massive waves and probably using chemical weapons... It could get ugly real quick... IMHO... Respectfully, SUNLINER81 I do not see the DPRK initiating a first strike with nukes, they have very little to gain and everything to lose by doing so. As far as their army "pouring" across the border, please do not forget that there are over 600K well-trained South Korean troops to oppose them and that any massing of DPRK formations will open them up to air strikes and, if chemical weapons are used, retailation in kind. Given 7-10 days time, we could have the USMC out of Okinawa, USAF assets from the region, and the rest of the 2 ID in country. The follow-on plans we have are very detailed and can be put in motion rather quickly. Plus I find it hard to believe that any country would stand with the DPRK if they did employ nukes. I can not see China trading economic status or any of their military installations to support the DPRK. The DPRK is not as well equiped to attack south as people think. In the end it would be 1,000,000 partially trained and fed DPRK troops versus 600K+ ROK troops backed up by a couple of US divisions with lots of air support (USN/USMC/USAF). It is not June of 1950. As far as them running their mouths, what is new about this? They have been doing it for 55+ years.

Respectfully, SUNLINER81 I do not see the DPRK initiating a first strike with nukes, they have very little to gain and everything to lose by doing so. As far as their army "pouring" across the border, please do not forget that there are over 600K well-trained South Korean troops to oppose them and that any massing of DPRK formations will open them up to air strikes and, if chemical weapons are used, retailation in kind. Given 7-10 days time, we could have the USMC out of Okinawa, USAF assets from the region, and the rest of the 2 ID in country. The follow-on plans we have are very detailed and can be put in motion rather quickly. Plus I find it hard to believe that any country would stand with the DPRK if they did employ nukes. I can not see China trading economic status or any of their military installations to support the DPRK. The DPRK is not as well equiped to attack south as people think. In the end it would be 1,000,000 partially trained and fed DPRK troops versus 600K+ ROK troops backed up by a couple of US divisions with lots of air support (USN/USMC/USAF). It is not June of 1950. As far as them running their mouths, what is new about this? They have been doing it for 55+ years. Let's hope you are right... Just remember, you are dealing with communists, the last of the "truly repressive" regimes and the PRC, which is still a "communist" government... Different philosophy on the loss of human life, in two countries that still have problems, especially N.Korea, in feeding the masses of people... All of N.Korea is hungry and repressed, so in short, a "population loss" to them, would not be a "big thing", unless it was for propaganda purposes... IMHO... Respectfully, SUNLINER81

content: quote: Originally posted by SUNLINER81: It may go nuclear and quick, with a "nuke" strike on Seoul and a retaliatory strike by the U.S. on the N.Korean capital of Pyongyang... The N.Korean army would, if they hadn't already, pour across the border in massive waves and probably using chemical weapons... It could get ugly real quick... IMHO... Respectfully, SUNLINER81 I do not see the DPRK initiating a first strike with nukes, they have very little to gain and everything to lose by doing so. As far as their army "pouring" across the border, please do not forget that there are over 600K well-trained South Korean troops to oppose them and that any massing of DPRK formations will open them up to air strikes and, if chemical weapons are used, retailation in kind. Given 7-10 days time, we could have the USMC out of Okinawa, USAF assets from the region, and the rest of the 2 ID in country. The follow-on plans we have are very detailed and can be put in motion rather quickly. Plus I find it hard to believe that any country would stand with the DPRK if they did employ nukes. I can not see China trading economic status or any of their military installations to support the DPRK. The DPRK is not as well equiped to attack south as people think. In the end it would be 1,000,000 partially trained and fed DPRK troops versus 600K+ ROK troops backed up by a couple of US divisions with lots of air support (USN/USMC/USAF). It is not June of 1950. As far as them running their mouths, what is new about this? They have been doing it for 55+ years.

content: quote: Originally posted by SUNLINER81: It may go nuclear and quick, with a "nuke" strike on Seoul and a retaliatory strike by the U.S. on the N.Korean capital of Pyongyang... The N.Korean army would, if they hadn't already, pour across the border in massive waves and probably using chemical weapons... It could get ugly real quick... IMHO... Respectfully, SUNLINER81 I do not see the DPRK initiating a first strike with nukes, they have very little to gain and everything to lose by doing so. As far as their army "pouring" across the border, please do not forget that there are over 600K well-trained South Korean troops to oppose them and that any massing of DPRK formations will open them up to air strikes and, if chemical weapons are used, retailation in kind. Given 7-10 days time, we could have the USMC out of Okinawa, USAF assets from the region, and the rest of the 2 ID in country. The follow-on plans we have are very detailed and can be put in motion rather quickly. Plus I find it hard to believe that any country would stand with the DPRK if they did employ nukes. I can not see China trading economic status or any of their military installations to support the DPRK. The DPRK is not as well equiped to attack south as people think. In the end it would be 1,000,000 partially trained and fed DPRK troops versus 600K+ ROK troops backed up by a couple of US divisions with lots of air support (USN/USMC/USAF). It is not June of 1950.
